hawaiian_text: (Ma ‘ane‘i e ‘ōlelo iki no kēlā mau inoa ‘elua, ‘o  ia ‘o Nāmakaokalani a me Nāmakaokai‘a, he mau  ali‘i nui lāua no Hawai‘i, he makua kāne ‘o  Nāmakaokalani a he keiki ‘o Nāmakaokai‘a, akā, ua  komo i loko o ka pule a Nāmakaokapāo‘o.)
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: In the old days, when the two names were spoken, these are Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai‘a, the great ali‘i of Hawai‘i. Nāmakaokalani is the father and Nāmakaokai‘a is the child. Therefore, they entered into the prayer of Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary:
• The passage encodes a dualistic cosmology reflecting the interplay between celestial and marine realms  
  – The names "Nāmakaokalani" (Eyes of the Sky) and "Nāmakaokai‘a" (Eyes of the Fish) symbolize the union of sky (Kahiko, the god of the heavens) and ocean (Kanaloa, the god of the sea), foundational elements in Hawaiian creation narratives  
  – The term "ali‘i nui lāua" (great ali‘i of Hawai‘i) highlights the sacred authority of the ruling class as mediators between divine and human worlds  

• Etymology and symbolic resonance of names  
  – **Nāmakaokalani**: "Nā-maka-o-ka-lani" (the eyes of the heavens) – "maka" (eyes) as metaphor for perception, "lani" (sky) as divine realm  
  – **Nāmakaokai‘a**: "Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a" (the eyes of the fish) – "i‘a" (fish) referencing the ocean's life-giving power, with "maka" (eyes) suggesting spiritual vision  
  – **Nāmakaokapāo‘o**: "Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o" (eyes of the prayer) – "pāo‘o" (prayer) as a sacred act, linking the names to ritual practices  

• Historical and cultural context of the 'Ai Kapu system  
  – The "ali‘i nui" (great chiefs) were central to the 'Ai Kapu (sacred dietary laws) that governed social hierarchy and spiritual practices pre-1819  
  – The phrase "ua komo i loko o ka pule" (entered into the prayer) may allude to the ritual incorporation of ali‘i into sacred spaces, a practice tied to the 'Ai Kapu's emphasis on maintaining sacred order  
  – Post-1820 missionary influence might have reinterpreted such terms through Christian lenses, though the structure here preserves pre-contact cosmology  

• Numerical symbolism and genealogical structure  
  – The "two names" ("kēlā mau inoa ‘elua") reflect the Hawaiian concept of *mo‘olelo* (history) as a duality, mirroring the creation of the world from the union of sky and ocean  
  – The father-son relationship ("makua kāne" and "keiki") underscores the hereditary transmission of spiritual and political power, a key feature of the ali‘i class  

• Social commentary on power and transformation  
  – The text critiques the rigid hierarchy of the 'Ai Kapu era by depicting ali‘i as both divine and mortal, their roles fluid between sacred and temporal realms  
  – "Entering the prayer" may symbolize the absorption of secular power into spiritual frameworks, a tension that would later be disrupted by 1819 abolition of kapu and missionary reforms
raw_response:
<translation>  
In the old days, when the two names were spoken, these are Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai‘a, the great ali‘i of Hawai‘i. Nāmakaokalani is the father and Nāmakaokai‘a is the child. Therefore, they entered into the prayer of Nāmakaokapāo‘o.  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
• The passage encodes a dualistic cosmology reflecting the interplay between celestial and marine realms  
  – The names "Nāmakaokalani" (Eyes of the Sky) and "Nāmakaokai‘a" (Eyes of the Fish) symbolize the union of sky (Kahiko, the god of the heavens) and ocean (Kanaloa, the god of the sea), foundational elements in Hawaiian creation narratives  
  – The term "ali‘i nui lāua" (great ali‘i of Hawai‘i) highlights the sacred authority of the ruling class as mediators between divine and human worlds  

• Etymology and symbolic resonance of names  
  – **Nāmakaokalani**: "Nā-maka-o-ka-lani" (the eyes of the heavens) – "maka" (eyes) as metaphor for perception, "lani" (sky) as divine realm  
  – **Nāmakaokai‘a**: "Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a" (the eyes of the fish) – "i‘a" (fish) referencing the ocean's life-giving power, with "maka" (eyes) suggesting spiritual vision  
  – **Nāmakaokapāo‘o**: "Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o" (eyes of the prayer) – "pāo‘o" (prayer) as a sacred act, linking the names to ritual practices  

• Historical and cultural context of the 'Ai Kapu system  
  – The "ali‘i nui" (great chiefs) were central to the 'Ai Kapu (sacred dietary laws) that governed social hierarchy and spiritual practices pre-1819  
  – The phrase "ua komo i loko o ka pule" (entered into the prayer) may allude to the ritual incorporation of ali‘i into sacred spaces, a practice tied to the 'Ai Kapu's emphasis on maintaining sacred order  
  – Post-1820 missionary influence might have reinterpreted such terms through Christian lenses, though the structure here preserves pre-contact cosmology  

• Numerical symbolism and genealogical structure  
  – The "two names" ("kēlā mau inoa ‘elua") reflect the Hawaiian concept of *mo‘olelo* (history) as a duality, mirroring the creation of the world from the union of sky and ocean  
  – The father-son relationship ("makua kāne" and "keiki") underscores the hereditary transmission of spiritual and political power, a key feature of the ali‘i class  

• Social commentary on power and transformation  
  – The text critiques the rigid hierarchy of the 'Ai Kapu era by depicting ali‘i as both divine and mortal, their roles fluid between sacred and temporal realms  
  – "Entering the prayer" may symbolize the absorption of secular power into spiritual frameworks, a tension that would later be disrupted by 1819 abolition of kapu and missionary reforms  
</commentary>
reference_translation: (Here, I’ll talk a little about those two names,  Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai‘a, which are  names of high chiefs of Hawai‘i. Nāmakaokalani  was the father and Nāmakaokai‘a was the son, but  these names were mentioned in the prayer of  Nāmakaokapāo‘o.)
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
